The student is recorded and assessed later, unlike the IELTS which places the candidate in front of an examiner. It exists in different forms : PBT: Paper-based test IBT: Internet-based test iBT: Scores range from 0 to 120. A score of 79 / 90 is required to pass PBT: final scores range from 310 to 677 and does not include written exam score. Since the ETS introduced the TOEFL Internet-based Test in 2005, it has progressively replaced the paper-based Test (PBT) and the computer-based test (CBT). The CBT was discontinued in September 2006 whereas it is still possible to pass paper-based tests in limited areas. Minimum scores for admission in colleges and universities Each university or college sets a minimum score for admission into the school or into a program. It is not possible to state a minimum score here as each establishment is free to set a different minimum accepted score. To illustrate this, minimum scores for admission can range as low as 61. On the other hand, a university like Oxford requires a score as high as 111 out of 120 for admission. The TOEIC is the second standardised test here is managed by the US-based ETS. They have been administering it since its creation in 1979 by a Japanese team backed by the Japanese Ministry of Economy.

The following section establishes our principles and elaborates on the main dimensions of each principle in practice. Core Principle: Transparency Transparent AI ensures that information about the AI systems and related business processes is documented and disclosed to internal and external stakeholders. Communication and documentation of this information are structured, formalized into policies and procedures, and ensured for traceability, reliability, and auditability when needed. Transparency is supported by the sub-principles of: Explainability & interpretability and auditability. Explainability & Interpretability Explainability & interpretability place emphasis on the technical transparency of AI systems. To differentiate: Explainability is the ability to explain and validate the internal functioning of an AI system in human terms and to identify system success along with scenarios of system failure and error. Explainability is the ability to answer the why, how, and what? Leading to a deterministic behavior of AI models. Interpretability is the predictability of system outcomes following a change in input or parameters. Interpretability is achieved through the predictability of the outcome even when the reasoning behind it remains unexplainable. Interpretability is a locally valid approximation determined from specific inputs. Auditability Auditability is the readiness of the AI system and the organization for a review of algorithms, data, design, and processes. Auditability is the processes and measures put in place to enable understanding and transparent review. The auditing of AI systems and processes drives trust in the system and demonstrates the organizational considerations for transparency and ethics. Although the end goal of auditability is trust, another objective for organizations to pursue while integrating auditability mechanisms is the internal scrutiny of its systems which reveals potential errors and minimizes the probability of negative consequences and potential harm as well as the readiness for regulation-imposed audits. Core Principle: Data governance Data governance as a core principle of the framework ensures data responsibility to enable all other principles. A strong data governance foundation and established data management practices are crucial to responsible AI. Data Governance, as a practice, can be defined as the set of roles, processes, and tools that allow organizations to manage their data assets and assign specific roles to oversee control and authority over them. In this definition of data governance as a core principle of responsible AI, we mainly focus on the components of data governance that allow control over the data that feeds AI models and algorithms and influences outcomes and predictions of the systems. Data governance is supported by the sub-principles: User Data Rights & Privacy User Data Rights User data rights, as a sub-principle of responsible AI, focuses on mechanisms available to users and data subjects allowing them control over their personal data used for AI training and processing in AI projects. Respect for user data rights is crucial for data protection and compliance with data protection regulations and driving trust in AI as the ultimate objective. Privacy Data and privacy protection are now a business requirement. The privacy sub-principle focuses on mechanisms to be adopted by the organization in order to protect privacy and apply the principles of privacy-by-design and privacy-by-default which constitute the subject of article 25 of the GDPR Privacy-by-design ensures the integration of privacy into the products, processes, and systems from the early stages of the design through their lifecycle. Privacy-by-default is the principle according to which an organization (the data controller) ensures that only data strictly necessary for each specific purpose of the processing are processed by default (without the intervention of the user). Privacy is also addressed through the protection against data breaches and privacy threats. Core Principle: Responsibility Responsibility encompasses concepts that include the provision of trusted products and services, achieved through the implementation of well-defined principles and the establishment of an organizational culture of responsible AI. Fairness The pursuit of fairness includes: The avoidance of creating or reinforcing unfair bias inherent in data, Ensuring diversity in the datasets used in order to ensure equal treatment of all users. It is not enough to identify bias, what are the solutions to mitigate it? how can we monitor and adapt to overcome bias? These are the questions answered under the fairness principle. Accountability Accountability, as a driver for responsibility, answers the questions: Who is responsible for AI failure? Who is accountable in cases of negative consequences? Added value of accountability considerations: Help developers and product managers design and implement AI with a clear understanding of where liability lies for each decision, necessary action, and who to refer to for help and reporting. Autonomy Autonomy may be explained through two key factors The governance of AI autonomy The exercise of human agency and oversight following a defined autonomy model or governance mechanisms. Organizations need to define the degree of autonomy (decision-making power) delegated to AI and the degree of human agency and control performed by humans taking into account the specificity of each system, its business environment, and where it is in its lifecycle. Lawfulness & Compliance Lawfulness and compliance are addressed, as one principle, under two main dimensions: Compliance of AI systems and organizational policies and processes with all applicable international, local, and state obligations, regulations, and laws. Accordance of AI systems and organizational policies and processes with relevant international standards and industry best practices Core principle: Robustness This core principle deals with the issues of risk and unpredictability during AI operations. Robustness is upheld by principles that address the following interrelated dimensions: Prevention of harm and pre-emptive protection from adversarial threats. Meeting performance requirements. Assurance that the systems function as intended. Consequently, robustness is supported by the sub-principles: Safety & Security, Reliability, and Monitoring & moderation. Safety & Security This sub-principle is destined to address the dimensions of robustness that deal with the prevention and minimization of harm resulting from internal malfunctioning of AI systems, embodied in the sub-principle of safety, and safeguarding against external threats embodied in the security sub-principle. Reliability Reliability supports robustness by addressing the dimension of meeting performance requirements and operating as intended. Reliability includes accuracy, reproducibility, accounting for uncertainty, the ability to handle exceptions, and operating according to the intended purpose. Monitoring & Moderation This sub-principle calls for continuous monitoring, testing, and validation of AI systems first and foremost in the form of regular robustness checks. In cases where any risks to robustness are spotted, there should be mechanisms in place for the timely adaptation and moderation of the system to address these risks. Framework Architecture Foundational Architecture Responsible AI Enablers This assessment framework is built on two main categories of enablers: Processes & Technology: Trust-by-design Relevant technical enablers for integrating trust-by-design are mapped to the architecture of each principle to guide its assessment and set the building-blocks for its consequent improvement. People & Organization: Training, responsibilities, and communication Leadership commitment Leadership commitment and continuous sponsoring and support are crucial for the success of the implementation of a responsible AI program. Leadership involvement in all AI and RAI-related decisions and activities is outlined in the stakeholder engagement (RACI) matrices designed for each core principle defining the specific activities and responsibilities in need of leadership approval and involvement. Training & awareness Training engineers, data scientists, design & development teams as well as product managers on the skills needed to identify and manage risks and challenges that come with AI adoption via mandatory AI ethics (or RAI) trainings. Examples of RAI training include educating data scientists and engineers on how to interpret model outputs and decisions or how to detect and manage bias. Trainings are outlined in the organizational enablers of each principle where necessary and relevant and depending on the principle should cover legal and ethical considerations in AI. Moreover, In cases where there are customer-facing roles (customer relation, sales) that interact with ML models or use AI-enabled products, these individuals should be trained to be aware of the benefits, risks, and limitations of the system and its use and to identify and report ethical concerns. Broadly speaking, trainings should be tailored to each function and the responsibilities entrusted to the individual/ group in the context of RAI. The training and awareness enabler also aims to avoid gaps in the organization’s AI governance structure: A formalized training plan ensures proper role on-boarding, cross-functional knowledge-sharing, and a formalized, documented process for role handover in case of employee turnover in terms of the skills relevant to responsible AI. If major changes occur to the organizational structure, the AI governance organization should be immediately reviewed and reassigned. The end goal of RAI training plans is to create a community of RAI subject matter experts inside the organization and to create multidisciplinary, multifunctional RAI awareness. Culture & change management: This framework is designed to be adaptable to each client organization’s culture and values. The objectives of the program are determined on the basis of the client’s specific objectives and aspirations in terms of the RAI maturity to reach. However, RAI implementation is a cultural change that should be embraced by the people involved. Communication with stakeholders The communication enabler focuses on key decisions determining the responsible AI strategy as well as the establishment of effective feedback channels or mechanisms. Stakeholder engagement strategies should be continuously tested, reviewed, and improved to respond to changing requirements and shifts in the regulatory and business landscape.
question: How can one avoid issues with Gazebo installation while performing a clean installation of Ubuntu 22.04 on a test machine?
answer: To avoid issues with Gazebo installation while performing a clean installation of Ubuntu 22.04 on a test machine, it is recommended to perform the entire steps of installation in a Docker image, as provided in the relevant repository. This approach can help prevent common errors such as Gazebo installing improperly, which can result in 'ninja cannot find target' error messages during the make process.

Ask questions in the search bar (such as: "what is the guest wifi password"), and the algorithm will pull multiple sources within Happeo to provide you with an answer. By default, Happeo will search through the internal sources, but you can also choose to search through the integrations by clicking “Search from integrations” Where do you come in? question: What are some examples of digital technologies being used in healthcare and what are they used for?
answer: Some examples of digital technologies being used in healthcare include Big Data for storing and processing large amounts of data, IoT (Internet of Things) for connected devices, and Artificial Intelligence for data analysis. These technologies are used to collect data through connected devices, store and organize the data, and then use algorithms to analyze the data. Some specific applications of these technologies in healthcare include chirurgie assistée par ordinateur (computer-assisted surgery), aide à la décision diagnostique et thérapeutique (diagnostic and therapeutic decision support), and prévention et anticipation d'épidémies (epidemic prevention and anticipation).

oracle: Even though the content doesn’t really matter, it would be easier if a fictitious subject was given each time. Anyway, these exercises are welcome to put theory into practice. In addition to a nice form, the content of the coursebook is really interesting. It covers all the basics, from the introduction-body-conclusion rule to the subject-verb-other rule. It also includes some tips for individual or group communication, such as questions to ask ourselves before a meeting, pitfalls to avoid, how to make sure everyone is on the same wavelength, and so on. In a nutshell, the coursebook has a really interesting content, all presented in a clear and enjoyable format. Even if some points could be improved, such as the exercises, it is definitely worth reading. I hope that my writing skills are now up to the teaching quality of this book. Sophie VRVST Sophie’s feedback on the LTR1 coursebook Recently, Ingrid shared with me the LTR1 coursebook: “How to speak and write clearly”. Ingrid is our English teacher at Eura Nova. She is there to help us continuously improve our speaking, listening and writing skills in English. The coursebook was created to help us improve our communication skills. After reading it, Ingrid asked me to give some feedback on the content of the coursebook. Consequently, the following paragraphs contain the things that I liked in the document and some suggestions to enrich it. First of all, I found the coursebook well structured. The reader quickly understands that they will go from very big to very small. In other words, the coursebook starts with communication acts structure, then continues with thoughts and finishes with sentence structure. This allows the reader to integrate a reflection process that must happen before each communication act: start with questions about their objective, continue by organizing their thoughts and don’t forget to use simple sentences. Secondly, I liked the many examples in the coursebook.

The nr one thing to be aware of is that texts are made of paragraphs. In my editor and proofreader’s career, I have noted in the past five years or so that more and more people do not actually know what paragraphs must be made of for the sake of message clarity. So, here is either your first dose or your booster shot of this vital information to keep applying relentlessly until your last keyboard stroke: 'A paragraph is a distinct section of a piece of writing, usually dealing with a single theme and indicated by a new line, indentation, or numbering.' There is no such thing as a 'half paragraph, where I have seen people go sort of half-yes-half-no-surely-I-don't-know-so-I-ll-make-something-up kind of attitude, and made up some non-structures. Below is a very lovely example to help you grasp the notion of the paragraph. I picked it from a full text; it stood between two line spaces, which indicates that the author’s intention was to actually write a paragraph but you can probably already see by looking at it without starting to read that it is not. I picked it because, apart from the absence of structure, the content is really lovely and creates a nice feeling for Euranovian readers. Here it is: I will begin from the personal side, what does joining Eura Nova mean to me? I’m a 30 years old person, how after a successful career of 5 years as director manager, made up his mind to get out of his comfort zone to realize a dream !

GOVERNING TEXTS Source: Data Guidance/ Imen Enneifar (Tunisian Lawyer) 1.1. Legislation relevant to employee monitoring There is no specific Tunisian regulation relevant to employee staff monitoring. Organic Act no 2004-63 of July 27th 2004 on the Protection of Personal Data (only available in French and Arabic here) ('the Data Protection Law') does not specifically regulate this matter, however, the modernisation of the Data Protection Law is expected to cover this topic. The Tunisian data protection authority ('INPDP') published, on 15 March 2018, the Draft Law on the Protection of Personal Data. 1.2.

Comment ça marche? Les données traitées sont des données métagénomiques shotgun (abondance relative des différentes espèces de bactéries, description du metabolism à l’aide des Kegg pathways, …). Ces données sont tout d’abord traitées dans un pipeline de preprocessing développé par Maat Pharma. L’étude et les modèles sont développés dans un premier temps sur des données publiques, puis appliquées aux données Maat. Les données publiques correspondent à plusieurs cohortes de patients atteints de différents types de cancer et suivant un traitement par immunothérapie. Ces patients peuvent répondre positivement ou non au traitement.

question: How is the structure of the coursebook described in the document?
answer: The coursebook is described as starting with communication acts structure, then continuing with thoughts and finishing with sentence structure. This structure is designed to integrate a reflection process that must happen before each communication act, starting with questions about the objective, continuing by organizing thoughts, and finishing by using simple sentences.

oracle: Communication aims at reaching or consolidating an agreement, as a basic understanding that leads to fruitful decisions and actions. To keep this going, it is necessary to identify people’s needs and feelings. To do this, relevant questions have to be asked and empathy has to be the supporting backstage. For example, typical client’s emotions are the pleasure of receiving a new item or service they have long been dreaming of, fear of being cheated on, impatience to arrive at the end of the project. Asking questions as part of a constant onboarding dialogue implies finding out what our customer needs and seeking feedback about their satisfaction. A common mistake is to believe that we have asked the right questions; our need is to find out what will create value rapidly for them. Often, we simply don't know what the best interest of the client company is. In other words, we fail to grasp the core of their system and values. Asking questions needs to be done at all stages of the communication process. It is an art to find the relevant questions to ask without wasting time and without coming across as intrusive.

9. PENALTIES Since there is no specific Tunisian regulation relevant to employee monitoring and the Data Protection Law is silent on this matter, there are no relevant penal sanctions or penalties. However, please be advised that the Data Protection Law provides for both civil and criminal sanctions regarding the processing or the transfer of human resource data outside Tunisia, without obtaining prior authorisation from the INPDP. Articles 86 to 105 of the Data Protection Law provide for both criminal and civil sanctions. A penalty of one-year imprisonment and a fine of TND 5,000 (approx. €1,500) may be enforced against any employer who intentionally processes personal data without the submitting the prior notification required by the INPDP. The Data Protection Law states that a penalty of two years imprisonment and a fine of TND 10,000 (approx. €3,000) may be enforced against any employer who processes sensitive personal data without prior authorisation from the INPDP. The Data Protection Law adds that a penalty of one year imprisonment and a fine of TND 10,000 (approx. €3,000) may be enforced against any employer who uses fraud, violence or threats to gain consent from a person for the processing of their personal data. Moreover, a penalty of one-year imprisonment and a fine of TND 5,000 (approx. €1,500) are applicable to the data controller and the sub-contractor who continue the processing of personal data despite the objection of the data subject. Do you see what I mean? The conclusion is your objective; it is what you and the people you interact with bothered spending time and effort on the communication act at hand. It is what it is all about in the end. So: don’t make a blunder of it! What do you think should be in a conclusion? Usually, things end with an expressed acknowledgement that the goal was reached. “Well, here we are; we said we would come up with the solution to Life, the Universe and Everything and we did: it is 42”. Conclusions often have a synthesis or a brief summary of the path walked on by the communication partners: “We started on Planet Earth and its many problems, we flew to the Moon and then to Mars. There we found a Brave New World that led us to … 42.” To finish, conclusions should be a springboard to what comes after the communication act that just ended; it can also be food for thought for the future. Here are a few examples: “Now let me ask: what is this discovery inspiring you to do now?” When making a public presentation: “I will give my next X-talk on how to keep your hubby happy in XYZ place on the XYZ date. You are all cordially invited!” When closing a business meeting; “Can we all note that the next action for X, Y and Z is to do … by - date - and for us all to meet again on…?” “Excuse me, Mr Chairman, could someone perhaps write on the board what the next steps are so we are all on the same page?” Practice 3: Think of a couple of communication acts that finished on a flop and write down what you could have said or asked to prevent this: - - Right. We have covered how to structure overall communication acts. Now let’s move one step down and into structuring units of thought and how to connect them to one another. 2.2. Point 2. Structure of one thought To express one thought, it is very helpful to think in terms of priorities within that thought. In a text, one unit of thought usually corresponds to a paragraph. In speaking, one unit of thought usually finishes when the speaker pauses for a longer breath and changes pitch, with the voice going down more than at the end of a sentence, but less than at the end of the whole speech.

question: How does asking relevant questions contribute to effective communication and understanding a client's needs and values?
answer: Asking relevant questions significantly contributes to effective communication by helping to identify people's needs and feelings, reach agreements, and foster fruitful decisions and actions. It enables finding out what the customer needs, seeking feedback about their satisfaction, and understanding the client's core system and values. Asking questions needs to be practiced throughout the communication process as an art to find the right questions without wasting time or being intrusive. Common client emotions include pleasure, fear, and impatience, which can be discovered through constant onboarding dialogues.

Responsible AI Standardisation & Compliance Context In an evolving regulatory, ethical, and business landscape, organisations aiming to derive value from AI are faced with the challenge of adhering to ethical principles, gearing up for regulatory compliance, and aligning business processes and technical practices with international standards. To respond to these challenges, Euranova proposes its own Responsible AI framework which provides insights and guidance on how best to adapt to the changing AI landscape and ensure that organisations have the correct policies, procedures, and technical capabilities in place to guarantee ethical and responsible outcomes from AI adoption. These outcomes are ensured through the development of transparent, robust, privacy-preserving, and risk-aware machine learning models by organisations that are accountable and compliant. ﻿ The goal behind our work on responsible AI is to assist organisations in the trustworthy development, deployment, and use of AI. On the other hand, various international organisations are working on developing international standards for responsible AI. For example, the International Organization for Standardization (ISO) has established working groups to create standards related to AI ethics, bias mitigation, and other aspects of responsible AI. In Europe, the EU Commission is putting forth the European AI Act, a legislative proposal to regulate the development and use of AI as part of the EU’s broader strategy to establish a trustworthy and human-centric approach to AI. This internship aims to extend the existing RAI framework with a focus on exploring the RAI standardisation and regulatory landscape and benchmarking these efforts to our framework with the purpose of extending it based on the findings. Competencies We expect you to learn and develop your skills in the following areas: Knowledge of analytics, artificial intelligence, and business Knowledge of data management, data & AI governance, privacy, and risk management Knowledge of business process management Objectives This project is organised around upgrading the responsible AI framework. Research & Analysis: At this phase, the objective is to: Conduct structured and thoroughly documented research into AI and RAI standardisation frameworks. Review the requirements of the European AI Act and other AI legal frameworks. Explore ethical RAI tradeoffs and links to machine learning tradeoffs for responsible AI. Benchmarking: Use the findings of step 1 to map the reviewed standards and regulatory requirements to Euranova’s responsible AI framework. Evaluation: Evaluate the existing tools and resources to validate the conformity with the AI Act.

Each project is an opportunity to be actively involved in the development of solutions to address tomorrow’s challenges in ICTs and to implement them today, and can be developed into end-of-study projects or master's theses. In this string, we are going to dive into matters that may have a little more to do with conventions than with reasoning, so you have to accept them as they are, but you will also see that they mostly make sense, too. We are going to cover punctuation rules with a special focus on capitalisation. 6.1 Punctuation Let’s, as always, learn from the best. Here is what English Grammar Today from the Cambridge Dictionary organisation says about this all-important piece in the puzzle of good writing: The most common punctuation marks in English are: capital letters and full stops, question marks, commas, colons and semi-colons, exclamation marks and quotation marks. In speaking, we use pauses and the pitch of the voice to make what we say clear. Punctuation plays a similar role in writing, making it easier to read. Punctuation consists of both rules and conventions. There are rules of punctuation that have to be followed, but there are also punctuation conventions that give writers greater choice. Punctuation: capital letters (B, D) and full stops (.) We use capital letters to mark the beginning of a sentence and we use full stops to mark the end of a sentence, [...] We also use capital letters at the beginning of proper nouns. Proper nouns include personal names (including titles before names), nationalities and languages, days of the week and months of the year, public holidays as well as geographical places: Dr David James is the consultant at Leeds City Hospital.

The standard structure for writing emails is: (1) Subject line, (2) Greetings, (3) Reason for writing, (4) Some short sentences with standard phrases picked according to the purpose of your email, (5) Attaching files, (6) Ending, (7) Closing formula. Since we have covered the subject line above, let’s start with greetings. GREETINGS Formal When you do not know at all who will be reading your letter: To whom it may concern: When you do not know if the reader is a man or a woman and you do not know their name: Dear sir/madam, When writing to a man whose name you know and who does not have a title: Dear Mr Xyz, When writing to a man whose name you know and who does not have a title: Dear Ms Xyz, When writing to a person with a title: Dear Dr Xyz, Dear Prof. Xyz, Dear Mr President, Dear Madam President, … First names are not used. Using Miss or Mrs to address a woman is no longer appropriate. Informal Hi Dennis, Hello Claire, Dear Mum, Salutations are followed by a (,) comma, with an exception: 'To whom it may concern:' REASON FOR WRITING / REPLYING Formal I am writing to make a reservation/ to apply for the position of.../ to confirm my booking/ to ask for further information about ... I am writing with regard to the sale of .../ to the complaint you made on 29th February Thank you for your email of 29th February regarding the sale of...

A report submitted in fulfillment of the requirements for Course XYZ, Department of XYZ, EURA NOVA. (Example of terms of reference) Summary (Abstract) The summary should briefly describe the content of the report. It should cover the aims of the report, what was found and what, if any, action is called for. Aim for about 1/2 a page in length and avoid detail or discussion; just outline the main points. Remember that the summary is the first thing that is read. It should provide the reader with a clear, helpful overview of the content of the report. Contents (Table of Contents) The contents page should list the different chapters and/or headings together with the page numbers. Your contents page should be presented in such a way that the reader can quickly scan the list of headings and locate a particular part of the report. You may want to number chapter headings and subheadings in addition to providing page references. Whatever numbering system you use, be sure that it is clear and consistent throughout. Introduction The introduction sets the scene for the main body of the report.

It is an attitude of transparent bodily posture and messages. Here are its features: Open mind Body language and facial expressions: Visible yet contained smiling (if in line with the message to convey) Use of body to serve the meaning Maintaining expressive eye contact Way of speaking: Clear message Calm and lively Appropriate tone Words come easily Structured sentences Speaking at the right moment Answering questions without delay Interacting with the intent of getting to a solution Learning to become assertive can be quite hard for some of us used to other types of behaviour. For example, eye contact is critical in assertive communication; you need to establish it and to keep eye contact, but a strong gaze can be considered aggressive. Overdoing body language could be a sign of non-assertiveness. It is all about balance and experience. Body language varies also from culture to culture: should you work with international colleagues or clients, be aware they might display different body language or not understand the subtleties of yours. Assertive communication is in opposition to passive, aggressive, manipulative communication. For more information on these behaviours, and things such as the difference between inclusive humour and segregating sarcasm, please refer to LTR 6 How to Avoid Conflict with Simple Language. In it, you will learn to do things like: know your strengths and weaknesses, display an open attitude, say what you mean, mean what you say, and don’t be mean when you say it, be proactive, mind your appearance, voice, tone, eye contact, body language, tune in with your audience, anticipate questions and pitfalls, time it right, mind other’s usual way of thinking, speak their language at first, prepare constructive statements, know the point of no return, know the person’s highest values, make things real and tangible, use a spiral approach, spot omissions and distortions, state why you ask questions, listen with empathy, listen to yourself, what others say and what they don’t say, observe facts, feel the affected part of your body, develop a vocabulary for emotions, accept responsibility, empower yourself, manage your feelings, stay in emotional audit mode, have key phrases to express your needs, rephrase your counterpart’s need, suggest action, make clear requests, find the blocking points, and much more!

Nos domaines d’expertise sont les architectures de données, l’intelligence artificielle et l’incubation de produit. Cette expertise est soutenue et nourrie par nos activités scientifiques qui se concentrent sur les techniques de machine learning, la théorie des graphes, le calcul haute performance et distribué. EURA NOVA Marseille est notre première implantation française, principalement orientée vers la recherche, en particulier le machine learning et la bioinformatique. Depuis 2017, elle dispose de l’agrément CIR du ministère de l’Enseignement Supérieur, de la Recherche et de l’Innovation. Comment travailler avec nous Notre mission est d’allier notre connaissance en science des données et nos compétences techniques à l’expertise particulière de nos partenaires afin de résoudre leurs problématiques. EURA NOVA met un point d’honneur à s’adapter aux besoins et aux procédures de ses partenaires.

For which purposes may an employer carry out this type of monitoring? Real-time listening and sound recording of calls in the workplace can be done in cases of a recognised need and must be proportionate to the objectives pursued. Thus, the employer can install a listening device and/or a time-activated system for recording phone calls when: evaluating employees (e.g. call centre workers); improving the quality of service (e.g.by studying the type of responses provided to the client); and creating analysis documents (reports or analysis grids), which can be written on the basis of recorded phone conversations as long as it fits in with these objectives. In light of this, the employer must collect and process only information necessary for the purpose pursued.

question: How can the accuracy of detected clusters in a UMAP plot be evaluated?
answer: In a supervised clustering problem, you can apply classification use-case accuracy checks in addition to clustering checks. For evaluating the Silhouette score, you can use the UMAP plot created in Notebook 5.1 (d) and check if the score is positive and above 0.3. A positive score above 0.3 indicates that the clusters are distinct and well-formed. Observing the UMAP plot, you can assess if the detected clusters match the clusters that are visually apparent. Additionally, you can analyze the accuracy of the clustering algorithm by examining misassigned points and their impact on the overall cluster formation.

distractors: The model’s prediction on an image returns a vector, in which each component corresponds to a specific class of animals. The value associated to each vector’s component provides the probability of presence of the associated animal class in the image. Regarding our example, the model recognize a thousand of animal classes. When applied to the ex ample image of a cat (fig. 2a), the model predicts the class ”Egyptian cat” with a probability of 62%. Knowing that the remaining 38% are spread over the 999 others classes, this 62% is an unambiguous result. If we now make local modifications to the image, such as masking a portion behind a black shape, we obtain the altered image depicted in Figure 2b. When the model is applied again to this altered image, the class ”Egyptian cat” is still recognized. However, the alteration has the effect of reducing the associated probability to 59%. By repeatedly performing this process of altering and evaluating the image, we accumulate insights into how each alteration influences the prediction score. When a sufficient amount of data is generated, the organization of the results allows the extraction of the significance of each part of the image to explain the prediction. This information can be presented as a heat-map (fig.2c), where high values represent the significant areas towards the prediction score. This representation is commonly called a saliency map in the field of XAI. Figure 2c shows that the forehead of the cat is the most important part of the image toward the ”Egyptian cat” class prediction. The aforementioned procedure is the foundation of perturbation based explainability.

Un des point fondamental de la topologie est la généralisation de la notion de distance entre deux éléments d’un ensemble avec les espaces vectoriel normés et les espaces métrique ceci permet de structurer un certain nombre d’ensemble et ainsi de pouvoir généraliser la notion de continuité, de limite etc... La topologie est utilisée de manière plus ou moins directe dans un certain nombre de domaine mais les aspects les plus théoriques de la topologie avec les espaces topologiques n’ont que peut d’application. la Topologie algébrique : est un mélange des deux notion en mettant des raisonnement d’algèbre dans un cadre topologique, on y développe les notions de groupe d’homologie et de cohomologie. La topologie algébrique une branche qui est a priori très peu utilisée de manière appliquée c’est donc une grande surprise de voir qu’en machine learning ce domaine possède quelques applications. To avoid this kind of balderdash, before you write a paragraph or speak, ask yourself who will be the central character of that particular story, or what central thing it is about. Name that person or that thing as the subject of your first sentence and then continue with pronouns. Are you the central person who does, is, feels, or to whom things happen? Then, start and continue your paragraph with “I”. Are you talking of another person or animal or other people or animals whom you have identified expressly in your first sentence? Then continue your paragraph with “he”, or “she”, or “they”. Make sure “he, she, they” do not stand for any other person until you expressly mention a change in person. Are you talking about some thing or some notion? Follow the same process as for animated beings, except here your pronouns will be “it” and “they”. Identify the central character/topic of your paragraph/idea. Assertiveness is not passive. Passive communication, that is - non-communication - is the one I truly despise! How disrespectful is it to receive an email, a phone call, a message, and not reply? How hurtful is it to avoid someone else’s attempt to make eye contact? I surely need to make progress on the path to equanimity, but truly, showing indifference to someone who reaches out is not only rude: it is hurtful and despicable! Besides, it doesn’t help anyone, does it? There are other forms of passive communication than failing to provide a reply to someone who is reaching out, for example, the one where the passive person accepts, admits, obeys, when in reality they do not wish to. In this case, passive communicators do not respect their own needs; they prefer to 'do it' out of fear of something or someone. In situations of extreme danger, it has been known to be life-saving, but, generally, this attitude just lets others take advantage. Another form of passive communication is the simple negligence to provide a reliable answer. But sometimes, the reason you don’t reply to a question is that you don’t know the answer, isn’t it? What to do in that case? Practice 3 How can you avoid being a passive communicator when you don’t know the answer to a question? How about replying this: 'I don’t know the answer.' Then, if possible, offer some alternative, such as 'Would you like me to look for it and come back to you on this?', or this: 'I don’t know the answer to your question just now but I will enquire about it and I will provide you with information by [date], if only to say that I could not find the answer.' Being a passive communicator creates insecurity and frustration on its receiving end, which can lead to tense exchanges or to a break-up. Don’t leave things hanging, provide reassurance, whether it be in the form of a deadline or other.

question: How can an Agile methodology contribute to delivering PoCs by focusing on constant value creation and alignment between needs and solutions?
answer: The Agile methodology is a good approach for delivering Proof of Concepts (PoCs) in a step-by-step manner, focusing from the beginning on the value created and ensuring consistent alignment between needs and solutions. This is achieved through close proximity to the business, which allows for better understanding and adaptation to the changing requirements and priorities.
